Comment: including both lexical adjectives and perfective participles of verbs
Several types of modifiers can (optionally) be used prenominally, see section 3.1.3.2 in Hualde & Ortiz de Urbina(2003) for more discussion.
adjectives in attributive position cannot take dependents (unless turned into prenominal RCs)
adjectives in attributive position cannot take dependents (unless turned into prenominal RCs)
When a degree modifier occurs inside a noun phrase with a head noun, the modifier precedes the noun while the adjective follows.
Such order is allowed in the past, and can still be used in eastern dialects (Hualde & Ortiz de Urbina__2003, p. 765).
Relative clauses must end with the finite verb form to which the complementizer is joined (Hualde & Ortiz de Urbina__2003, p. 765).

including modifiers consisting of constituents of adverbial function and the relational suffix -ko. Asides from postpositional phrases, other types of adverbials also include items such as lexical adverbs, case-marked NPs etc.See section 3.1.4.2 in Hualde & Ortiz de Urbina (2003) for more discussion.
